Description: Dice made in soft white limestone; small circular incised (or drilled) shallow depressions indicated on each side of the dice; the numbers of circles is not what is expected on a regular dice with two sides marked by seven circles, irregularly places on the surface, two sides with six depressions; at last one regular side with four circles and another one with five: rigged dice?
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Since this dice presents several sides with high numbers, it is possible to consider this dice as rigged. For another example of rigged dice from Naukratis, see BM 1886,0401.1719. The holes of this latter example are filled with lead.

Numerous solid six-sided (cubic) dice, predominantly of limestone with drilled pips (but also of faience, ivory, marble, pumice and terracotta) were found at Naukratis. Parallels known from the 7th century BC, but are particularly popular in the Roman period (Cool 2016, 229-231). Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TH.09)
Condition: Relatively fair though the soft stone is slightly eroded.
